trans-unit.source: Note that $_ is an alias to the list value, so it can be used to modify the elements of the LIST. While this is useful and supported, it can cause bizarre results if the elements of LIST are not variables. Using a regular foreach loop for this purpose would be clearer in most cases. See also grep for an array composed of those items of the original list for which the BLOCK or EXPR evaluates to true.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que $_ es un alias del valor de la lista, por lo que se puede utilizar para modificar los elementos de la LISTA. Si bien esto es útil y compatible, puede generar resultados extraños si los elementos de LIST no son variables. Usar un bucle foreach regular para este propósito sería más claro en la mayoría de los casos. Consulte también grep para obtener una matriz compuesta por los elementos de la lista original para los que BLOCK o EXPR se evalúan como verdaderos.

trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que tr qué no hacer clases regulares de carácter expresión tales como \d o \pL . El operador tr no es equivalente a la utilidad tr(1) . Los escapes de interpolación de cadenas \U , \u , \L y \l en el lado derecho de un operador de sustitución realizarán mapeos de mayúsculas y minúsculas correctos, pero tr[a-z][A-Z] no lo hará (excepto a veces en datos heredados de 7 bits).

trans-unit.source: Note that cx_pushblock() sets two new floors: for the args stack (to MARK) and the temps stack (to PL_tmps_ix). While executing at this scope level, every nextstate (amongst others) will reset the args and tmps stack levels to these floors. Note that since cx_pushblock uses the current value of PL_tmps_ix rather than it being passed as an arg, this dictates at what point cx_pushblock should be called. In particular, any new mortals which should be freed only on scope exit (rather than at the next nextstate) should be created first.

Note that undef is treated much as other numerical operations treat it; it compares equal to zero but additionally produces a warning if such warnings are enabled (use warnings 'uninitialized';). Note that undef is treated much as other numerical operations treat it; it compares equal to zero but additionally produces a warning if such warnings are enabled (use warnings 'uninitialized';). In addition, an undef in the returned list is coerced into a numerical zero, so that the entire list of values returned by uniqnum are well-behaved as numbers.

Note that undef is treated much as other string operations treat it; it compares equal to the empty string but additionally produces a warning if such warnings are enabled (use warnings 'uninitialized';). In addition, an undef in the returned list is coerced into an empty string, so that the entire list of values returned by uniqstr are well-behaved as strings.

trans-unit.source: Note that Perl can be compiled and run under either ASCII or EBCDIC (See perlebcdic). Most of the documentation (and even comments in the code) ignore the EBCDIC possibility. For almost all purposes the differences are transparent. As an example, under EBCDIC, instead of UTF-8, UTF-EBCDIC is used to encode Unicode strings, and so whenever this documentation refers to utf8 (and variants of that name, including in function names), it also (essentially transparently) means UTF-EBCDIC . But the ordinals of characters differ between ASCII, EBCDIC, and the UTF- encodings, and a string encoded in UTF-EBCDIC may occupy more bytes than in UTF-8.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que Perl puede compilarse y ejecutarse en ASCII o EBCDIC (consulte perlebcdic ). La mayor parte de la documentación (e incluso los comentarios en el código) ignoran la posibilidad de EBCDIC. Para casi todos los propósitos, las diferencias son transparentes. Como ejemplo, bajo EBCDIC, en lugar de UTF-8, se usa UTF-EBCDIC para codificar cadenas Unicode, por lo que siempre que esta documentación se refiere a utf8 (y variantes de ese nombre, incluso en los nombres de funciones), también (esencialmente de forma transparente) significa UTF-EBCDIC . Pero los ordinales de los caracteres difieren entre las codificaciones ASCII, EBCDIC y UTF, y una cadena codificada en UTF-EBCDIC puede ocupar más bytes que en UTF-8.

trans-unit.source: Note that Perl can be compiled and run under either ASCII or EBCDIC (See perlebcdic). Most of the documentation (and even comments in the code) ignore the EBCDIC possibility. For almost all purposes the differences are transparent. As an example, under EBCDIC, instead of UTF-8, UTF-EBCDIC is used to encode Unicode strings, and so whenever this documentation refers to utf8 (and variants of that name, including in function names), it also (essentially transparently) means UTF-EBCDIC. But the ordinals of characters differ between ASCII, EBCDIC, and the UTF- encodings, and a string encoded in UTF-EBCDIC may occupy a different number of bytes than in UTF-8.

trans-unit.source: Note that all C programs (including the perl interpreter, which is written in C) always have an underlying locale. That locale is the "C" locale unless changed by a call to setlocale(). When Perl starts up, it changes the underlying locale to the one which is indicated by the "ENVIRONMENT". When using the POSIX module or writing XS code, it is important to keep in mind that the underlying locale may be something other than "C", even if the program hasn't explicitly changed it.

Note that all C programs (including the perl interpreter, which is written in C) always have an underlying locale. That locale is the "C" locale unless changed by a call to setlocale(). When Perl starts up, it changes the underlying locale to the one which is indicated by the ENVIRONMENT. When using the POSIX module or writing XS code, it is important to keep in mind that the underlying locale may be something other than "C", even if the program hasn't explicitly changed it.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que todos los programas en C (incluido el intérprete de perl, que está escrito en C) siempre tienen una configuración regional subyacente. Esa configuración regional es la configuración regional "C" a menos que se modifique mediante una llamada a setlocale () . Cuando se inicia Perl, cambia la configuración regional subyacente a la indicada por ENVIRONMENT . Al utilizar el módulo POSIX o escribir código XS, es importante tener en cuenta que la configuración regional subyacente puede ser diferente a "C", incluso si el programa no la ha cambiado explícitamente.

trans-unit.source: Note that almost all properties are immune to case-insensitive matching. That is, adding a /i regular expression modifier does not change what they match. But there are two sets that are affected. The first set is Uppercase_Letter, Lowercase_Letter, and Titlecase_Letter, all of which match Cased_Letter under /i matching. The second set is Uppercase, Lowercase, and Titlecase, all of which match Cased under /i matching. (The difference between these sets is that some things, such as Roman numerals, come in both upper and lower case, so they are Cased, but aren't considered to be letters, so they aren't Cased_Letters. They're actually Letter_Numbers.) This set also includes its subsets PosixUpper and PosixLower, both of which under /i match PosixAlpha.

Note that almost all properties are immune to case-insensitive matching. That is, adding a /i regular expression modifier does not change what they match. There are two sets that are affected. The first set is Uppercase_Letter , Lowercase_Letter , and Titlecase_Letter , all of which match Cased_Letter under /i matching. The second set is Uppercase , Lowercase , and Titlecase , all of which match Cased under /i matching. (The difference between these sets is that some things, such as Roman numerals, come in both upper and lower case, so they are Cased , but aren't considered to be letters, so they aren't Cased_Letter s. They're actually Letter_Number s.) This set also includes its subsets PosixUpper and PosixLower , both of which under /i match PosixAlpha .
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que casi todas las propiedades son inmunes a la coincidencia que no distingue entre mayúsculas y minúsculas. Es decir, agregar un modificador de expresión regular /i no cambia lo que coinciden. Hay dos conjuntos afectados. El primer conjunto es Uppercase_Letter , Lowercase_Letter , y Titlecase_Letter , todos los cuales coincide con Cased_Letter bajo /i coincidente. El segundo conjunto es Uppercase , Lowercase , y Titlecase , todos los cuales coinciden con Cased bajo /i coincidente. (La diferencia entre estos conjuntos es que algunas cosas, como los números romanos, vienen en mayúsculas y minúsculas, por lo que son Cased , pero no se consideran letras, por lo que no son Cased_Letter s. En realidad son Letter_Number s.) Este conjunto también incluye sus subconjuntos PosixUpper y PosixLower , los cuales bajo /i coinciden con PosixAlpha .

trans-unit.source: Note that anything inside a \Q...\E stays unaffected by /x. And note that /x doesn't affect space interpretation within a single multi-character construct. For example in \x{...} , regardless of the /x modifier, there can be no spaces. Same for a quantifier such as {3} or {5,} . Similarly, (?:...) can't have a space between the (, ?, and : . Within any delimiters for such a construct, allowed spaces are not affected by /x, and depend on the construct. For example, \x{...} can't have spaces because hexadecimal numbers don't have spaces in them. But, Unicode properties can have spaces, so in \p{...} there can be spaces that follow the Unicode rules, for which see Properties accessible through \p{} and \P{} in perluniprops.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que cualquier cosa dentro de \Q...\E no se ve afectada por /x . Y tenga en cuenta que /x no afecta la interpretación del espacio dentro de una única construcción de varios caracteres. Por ejemplo, en \x{...} , independientemente del modificador /x , no puede haber espacios. Lo mismo para un cuantificador como {3} o {5,} . De manera similar, (?:...) no puede tener un espacio entre ( , ? , Y : . Dentro de cualquier delimitador para tal construcción, los espacios permitidos no se ven afectados por /x , y dependen de la construcción. Por ejemplo, \x{...} no puede tener espacios porque los números hexadecimales no tienen espacios en ellos. Pero, las propiedades Unicode pueden tener espacios, por lo que en \p{...} puede haber espacios que sigan las reglas Unicode, para lo cual vea Propiedades accesibles a través de \ p {} y \ P {} en perluniprops .

trans-unit.source: Note that anything inside a \Q...\E stays unaffected by /x. And note that /x doesn't affect space interpretation within a single multi-character construct. For example in \x{...}, regardless of the /x modifier, there can be no spaces. Same for a quantifier such as {3} or {5,}. Similarly, (?:...) can't have a space between the "(", "?", and ":". Within any delimiters for such a construct, allowed spaces are not affected by /x, and depend on the construct. For example, \x{...} can't have spaces because hexadecimal numbers don't have spaces in them. But, Unicode properties can have spaces, so in \p{...} there can be spaces that follow the Unicode rules, for which see "Properties accessible through \p{} and \P{}" in perluniprops.

Note that because multiple extensions may be using PERL_MAGIC_ext or PERL_MAGIC_uvar magic, it is important for extensions to take extra care to avoid conflict. Typically only using the magic on objects blessed into the same class as the extension is sufficient. For PERL_MAGIC_ext magic, it is usually a good idea to define an MGVTBL , even if all its fields will be 0 , so that individual MAGIC pointers can be identified as a particular kind of magic using their magic virtual table. mg_findext provides an easy way to do that:
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que debido a que varias extensiones pueden usar PERL_MAGIC_ext o PERL_MAGIC_uvar magic, es importante que las extensiones tengan un cuidado especial para evitar conflictos. Por lo general, solo es suficiente usar la magia en objetos bendecidos en la misma clase que la extensión. Para la magia PERL_MAGIC_ext , generalmente es una buena idea definir un MGVTBL , incluso si todos sus campos serán 0 , de modo que los punteros MAGIC individuales puedan identificarse como un tipo particular de magia usando su tabla virtual mágica. mg_findext proporciona una manera fácil de hacerlo:

De cualquier manera, la implementación no generará resultados mayores que el tamaño del tipo entero con el que se construyó Perl (32 bits o 64 bits).

Note that connected() considers a half-open TCP socket to be "in a connected state". Specifically, connected() does not distinguish between the ESTABLISHED and CLOSE-WAIT TCP states; it returns the peer address, rather than undef, in either case. Thus, in general, connected() cannot be used to reliably learn whether the peer has initiated a graceful shutdown because in most cases (see below) the local TCP state machine remains in CLOSE-WAIT until the local application calls shutdown() or close(); only at that point does connected() return undef.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que connected () considera que un socket TCP medio abierto está "en un estado conectado". Específicamente, connected () no distingue entre los estados TCP ESTABLECIDO y CLOSE-WAIT ; devuelve la dirección del par, en lugar de undef, en cualquier caso. Por lo tanto, en general, connected () no se puede usar para saber de manera confiable si el par ha iniciado un apagado ordenado porque en la mayoría de los casos (ver más abajo) la máquina de estado TCP local permanece en CLOSE-WAIT hasta que la aplicación local llama a shutdown () o close (); solo en ese punto, connected () devuelve undef.

Note that each pp_ function is expected to return a pointer to the next op. Calls to perl subs (and eval blocks) are handled within the same runops loop, and do not consume extra space on the C stack. For example, pp_entersub and pp_entertry just push a CxSUB or CxEVAL block struct onto the context stack which contain the address of the op following the sub call or eval. They then return the first op of that sub or eval block, and so execution continues of that sub or block. Later, a pp_leavesub or pp_leavetry op pops the CxSUB or CxEVAL , retrieves the return op from it, and returns it.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que se espera que cada función pp_ devuelva un puntero a la siguiente operación. Las llamadas a subs de perl (y bloques de evaluación) se manejan dentro del mismo bucle de runops y no consumen espacio adicional en la pila C. Por ejemplo, pp_entersub y pp_entertry simplemente insertan una estructura de bloque CxSUB o CxEVAL en la pila de contexto que contiene la dirección de la operación después de la sub llamada o eval. Luego devuelven la primera operación de ese sub o bloque de evaluación, y así continúa la ejecución de ese sub o bloque. Más tarde, una pp_leavesub o pp_leavetry saca el CxSUB o CxEVAL , recupera la operación de retorno y la devuelve.

trans-unit.source: Note that each pp_ function is expected to return a pointer to the next op. Calls to perl subs (and eval blocks) are handled within the same runops loop, and do not consume extra space on the C stack. They then return the first op of that sub or eval block, and so execution continues of that sub or block. Later, a pp_leavesub or pp_leavetry op pops the CxSUB or CxEVAL, retrieves the return op from it, and returns it.

Lo que sucede es que %s su operando simplemente se omiten sin previo aviso. https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=6530 .

Si usted quiere tener tales bytes bajo use utf8 , puede desactivar esta pragma hasta el final del bloque (o archivo, si en el nivel superior) por no utf8; .

Note that it is possible to have __DATA__ tokens in the same package in multiple files, and that the last __DATA__ token in a given package that is encountered by the compiler is the one accessible by the filehandle. This also applies to __END__ and main, i.e. if the 'main' program has an __END__ , but a module 'require'd (_not_ 'use'd) by that program has a 'package main;' declaration followed by an '__DATA__ ', then the DATA filehandle is set to access the data after the __DATA__ in the module, _not_ the data after the __END__ token in the 'main' program, since the compiler encounters the 'require'd file later.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que es posible tener tokens __DATA__ en el mismo paquete en varios archivos, y que el último token __DATA__ en un paquete dado que encuentra el compilador es el accesible por el identificador de archivo. Esto también se aplica a __END__ y main, es decir, si el programa 'principal' tiene un __END__ , pero un módulo 'requerido (_no_' usado) por ese programa tiene un 'paquete principal;' declaración seguida de un ' __DATA__ ', entonces el identificador de archivo DATA se establece para acceder a los datos después de __DATA__ en el módulo, _no_ los datos después del token __END__ en el programa 'principal', ya que el compilador encuentra el 'require'd archivo más tarde.

trans-unit.source: Note that it is possible to have __DATA__ tokens in the same package in multiple files, and that the last __DATA__ token in a given package that is encountered by the compiler is the one accessible by the filehandle. This also applies to __END__ and main, i.e. if the 'main' program has an __END__, but a module 'require'd (_not_ 'use'd) by that program has a 'package main;' declaration followed by an '__DATA__', then the DATA filehandle is set to access the data after the __DATA__ in the module, _not_ the data after the __END__ token in the 'main' program, since the compiler encounters the 'require'd file later.

trans-unit.source: Note that it's possible to confuse Perl into thinking // (the empty regex) is really // (the defined-or operator). Perl is usually pretty good about this, but some pathological cases might trigger this, such as $x/// (is that ($x) / (//) or $x // / ?) and print $fh // (print $fh(// or print($fh //?). In all of these examples, Perl will assume you meant defined-or. If you meant the empty regex, just use parentheses or spaces to disambiguate, or even prefix the empty regex with an m (so // becomes m//).
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que es posible confundir a Perl para que piense que // (la expresión regular vacía) es realmente // (el operador definido-or). Perl suele ser bastante bueno al respecto, pero algunos casos patológicos pueden desencadenar esto, como $x/// (es eso ($x) / (//) o $x // / ?) print $fh // imprimir $ fh // ( print $fh(// o print($fh // ?). En todos estos ejemplos, Perl asumirá que te refieres a definido-o. Si te refieres a la expresión regular vacía, simplemente usa paréntesis o espacios para eliminar la ambigüedad , o incluso prefijar expresión regular vacía con una m (entonces // se convierte en m// ).

trans-unit.source: Note that it's possible to confuse Perl into thinking // (the empty regex) is really // (the defined-or operator). Perl is usually pretty good about this, but some pathological cases might trigger this, such as $x/// (is that ($x) / (//) or $x // /?) and print $fh // (print $fh(// or print($fh //?). In all of these examples, Perl will assume you meant defined-or. If you meant the empty regex, just use parentheses or spaces to disambiguate, or even prefix the empty regex with an m (so // becomes m//).

trans-unit.source: Note that parentheses are necessary when you're chomping anything that is not a simple variable. Similarly, chomp $a, $b is interpreted as chomp($a), $b rather than as chomp($a, $b) .

Esto se debe a que chomp $cwd = `pwd`; se interpreta como (chomp $cwd) = `pwd`; , en lugar de como chomp( $cwd = `pwd` ) que podría esperar. De manera similar, chomp $a, $b se interpreta como chomp($a), $b lugar de chomp($a, $b) .

trans-unit.source: Note that starting from Perl 5.7.2 (and consequently 5.8.0) and AIX 4.3 or newer Perl uses the AIX native dynamic loading interface in the so called runtime linking mode instead of the emulated interface that was used in Perl releases 5.6.1 and earlier or, for AIX releases 4.2 and earlier. This change does break backward compatibility with compiled modules from earlier Perl releases. The change was made to make Perl more compliant with other applications like Apache/mod_perl which are using the AIX native interface. This change also enables the use of C++ code with static constructors and destructors in Perl extensions, which was not possible using the emulated interface.

Thus, for example, (?-p) will warn when compiled under use warnings; (?-d:...) and (?dl:...) are fatal errors.

trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que la a , d , l , p , y u modificadores son especiales en que sólo se pueden habilitar, no discapacitados, y la a , d , l , y u modificadores son mutuamente excluyentes: la especificación de uno de-especifica los otros, y puede aparecer un máximo de una (o dos a ) en el constructo. Así, por ejemplo, (?-p) advertirá cuando se compile bajo use warnings uso ; (?-d:...) y (?dl:...) son errores fatales.

Llame a $ ctx-> clone-> digest si desea calcular el resumen sin restablecer el estado del resumen.

trans-unit.source: Note that the API described here changed considerably in perl 5.24; prior to that, big macros like PUSHBLOCK and POPSUB were used; in 5.24 they were replaced by the inline static functions described below. Note that the MD5 algorithm is not as strong as it used to be. It has since 2005 been easy to generate different messages that produce the same MD5 digest. It still seems hard to generate messages that produce a given digest, but it is probably wise to move to stronger algorithms for applications that depend on the digest to uniquely identify a message.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que el algoritmo MD5 no es tan fuerte como sola ser.Desde 2005 ha sido fcil generar diferentes mensajes que producen el mismo resumen MD5.Sigue pareciendo difcil generar mensajes que produzcan un determinado compendio,pero probablemente sea conveniente pasar a algoritmos ms fuertes para aplicaciones que dependen del compendio para identificar un mensaje de manera nica.

Note that the implementation of seek in this module does not provide true random access to a compressed file/buffer. It works by uncompressing data from the current offset in the file/buffer until it reaches the uncompressed offset specified in the parameters to seek. For very small files this may be acceptable behaviour. For large files it may cause an unacceptable delay.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que la implementación de seek en este módulo no proporciona un verdadero acceso aleatorio a un archivo / búfer comprimido. Funciona descomprimiendo datos del desplazamiento actual en el archivo / búfer hasta que alcanza el desplazamiento sin comprimir especificado en los parámetros a seek . Para archivos muy pequeños, este puede ser un comportamiento aceptable. En el caso de archivos de gran tamaño, puede provocar un retraso inaceptable.

Note that the number of exponent digits in the scientific notation produced by %e , %E , %g and %G for numbers with the modulus of the exponent less than 100 is system-dependent: it may be three or less (zero-padded as necessary). In other words, 1.23 times ten to the 99th may be either "1.23e99" or "1.23e099". Similarly for %a and %A : the exponent or the hexadecimal digits may float: especially the "long doubles" Perl configuration option may cause surprises.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que el número de dígitos de exponente en la notación científica producida por %e , %E , %g y %G para los números con el módulo de la exponente menos de 100 es dependiente del sistema: puede ser de tres o menos (con relleno de ceros según sea necesario). En otras palabras, 1,23 por diez elevado a 99 puede ser "1,23e99" o "1,23e099". Del mismo modo para %a y %A : el exponente o los dígitos hexadecimales pueden flotar: especialmente la opción de configuración "largos dobles" Perl puede causar sorpresas.

trans-unit.source: Note that the number of exponent digits in the scientific notation produced by %e, %E, %g and %G for numbers with the modulus of the exponent less than 100 is system-dependent: it may be three or less (zero-padded as necessary). In other words, 1.23 times ten to the 99th may be either "1.23e99" or "1.23e099". Similarly for %a and %A: the exponent or the hexadecimal digits may float: especially the "long doubles" Perl configuration option may cause surprises.

Note that the only two changes from the normal way of writing an extension is the addition of a #define PERL_NO_GET_CONTEXT before including the Perl headers, followed by a dTHX; declaration at the start of every function that will call the Perl API. (You'll know which functions need this, because the C compiler will complain that there's an undeclared identifier in those functions.) No changes are needed for the XSUBs themselves, because the XS() macro is correctly defined to pass in the implicit context if needed.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que los únicos dos cambios con respecto a la forma normal de escribir una extensión es la adición de un #define PERL_NO_GET_CONTEXT antes de incluir los encabezados de Perl, seguido de un dTHX; declaración al comienzo de cada función que llamará a la API de Perl. (Sabrá qué funciones necesitan esto, porque el compilador de C se quejará de que hay un identificador no declarado en esas funciones). No se necesitan cambios para los XSUB en sí, porque la macro XS () está correctamente definida para pasar en el contexto implícito si es necesario.

Note that the parentheses in (?=regexp) and (?<=regexp) are non-capturing, since these are zero-width assertions. Thus in the second regexp, the substrings captured are those of the whole regexp itself. Lookahead (?=regexp) can match arbitrary regexps, but lookbehind (?<=fixed-regexp) only works for regexps of fixed width, i.e., a fixed number of characters long. Thus (?<=(ab|bc)) is fine, but (?<=(ab)*) is not. The negated versions of the lookahead and lookbehind assertions are denoted by (?!regexp) and (?<!fixed-regexp) respectively. They evaluate true if the regexps do
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que los paréntesis en (?=regexp) y (?<=regexp) no capturan, ya que son aserciones de ancho cero. Por lo tanto, en la segunda expresión regular, las subcadenas capturadas son las de toda la expresión regular. Lookahead (?=regexp) puede coincidir con expresiones regulares arbitrarias, pero lookbehind (?<=fixed-regexp) solo funciona para expresiones regulares de ancho fijo, es decir, un número fijo de caracteres. Entonces (?<=(ab|bc)) está bien, pero (?<=(ab)*) no lo está. Las versiones negadas de las afirmaciones de búsqueda anticipada y retrospectiva se indican mediante (?!regexp) y (?<!fixed-regexp) respectivamente. Evalúan verdadero si las expresiones regulares lo hacen

Note that the process will continue to grow for each file that it uses. In addition, there might be AUTOLOAD ed subroutines and other conditions that cause Perl's symbol table to grow. You might want to add some logic that keeps track of the process size, or restarts itself after a certain number of requests, to ensure that memory consumption is minimized. You'll also want to scope your variables with my whenever possible.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que el proceso seguirá creciendo para cada archivo que utilice. Además, puede haber subrutinas de AUTOLOAD ed y otras condiciones que hacen que la tabla de símbolos de Perl crezca. Es posible que desee agregar alguna lógica que realice un seguimiento del tamaño del proceso, o se reinicie después de una cierta cantidad de solicitudes, para garantizar que el consumo de memoria se minimice. También querrá establecer el alcance de sus variables con my siempre que sea posible.

trans-unit.source: Note that the process will continue to grow for each file that it uses. In addition, there might be AUTOLOADed subroutines and other conditions that cause Perl's symbol table to grow. You might want to add some logic that keeps track of the process size, or restarts itself after a certain number of requests, to ensure that memory consumption is minimized. You'll also want to scope your variables with "my" in perlfunc whenever possible.

Note that the properties of the algorithms change over time, as the algorithms are analyzed and machines grow faster. If your application for instance depends on it being "impossible" to generate the same digest for a different message it is wise to make it easy to plug in stronger algorithms as the one used grow weaker. Using the interface documented here should make it easy to change algorithms later.

trans-unit.source: Note that the third argument to open is a string containing the program name (sort) plus all its arguments: in this case, -u to specify unqiue sort, and then a fileglob specifying the files to sort. The resulting filehandle $sort_fh works just like a read-only ("<") filehandle, and your program can subsequently read data from it as if it were opened onto an ordinary, single file.

Note that the third argument, specifying the command that we wish to pipe to, sets up cat to redirect its output via that ">" symbol into the file numbered.txt. This can start to look a little tricky, because that same symbol would have meant something entirely different had it showed it in the second argument to open! But here in the third argument, it's simply part of the shell command that Perl will open the pipe into, and Perl itself doesn't invest any special meaning to it.

Note that there are quite a few things that are unaffected by the current locale. Any literal character is the native character for the given platform. Hence 'A' means the character at code point 65 on ASCII platforms, and 193 on EBCDIC. That may or may not be an 'A' in the current locale, if that locale even has an 'A'. Similarly, all the escape sequences for particular characters, \n for example, always mean the platform's native one. This means, for example, that \N in regular expressions (every character but new-line) works on the platform character set.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que hay bastantes cosas que no se ven afectadas por la configuración regional actual. Cualquier carácter literal es el carácter nativo de la plataforma dada. Por lo tanto, 'A' significa el carácter en el punto de código 65 en plataformas ASCII y 193 en EBCDIC. Eso puede ser o no una 'A' en la configuración regional actual, si esa configuración regional tiene siquiera una 'A'. De manera similar, todas las secuencias de escape para caracteres particulares, \n por ejemplo, siempre significan la nativa de la plataforma. Esto significa, por ejemplo, que \N en expresiones regulares (todos los caracteres excepto la nueva línea) funciona en el juego de caracteres de la plataforma.

trans-unit.source: Note that there is no unlock() function - the only way to unlock a variable is to allow it to go out of scope.

trans-unit.source: Note that there is no guarantee that the return value of SvPV() is equal to SvPVX(sv) , or that SvPVX(sv) contains valid data, or that successive calls to SvPV(sv) will return the same pointer value each time. This is due to the way that things like overloading and Copy-On-Write are handled. In these cases, the return value may point to a temporary buffer or similar. If you absolutely need the SvPVX field to be valid (for example, if you intend to write to it), then see SvPV_force.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que no hay garantía de que el valor de retorno de SvPV() sea igual a SvPVX(sv) , o que SvPVX(sv) contenga datos válidos, o que las sucesivas llamadas a SvPV(sv) devuelvan el mismo valor de puntero cada vez. Esto se debe a la forma en que se manejan cosas como la sobrecarga y la copia en escritura. En estos casos, el valor de retorno puede apuntar a un búfer temporal o similar. Si es absolutamente necesario que el campo SvPVX sea válido (por ejemplo, si tiene la intención de escribir en él), consulte SvPV_force .

trans-unit.source: Note that there is no guarantee that the return value of SvPV() is equal to SvPVX(sv), or that SvPVX(sv) contains valid data, or that successive calls to SvPV(sv) will return the same pointer value each time. This is due to the way that things like overloading and Copy-On-Write are handled. In these cases, the return value may point to a temporary buffer or similar. If you absolutely need the SvPVX field to be valid (for example, if you intend to write to it), then see "SvPV_force".

trans-unit.source: Note that this API requires disambiguation between successful decoding a NUL character, and an error return (unless the UTF8_CHECK_ONLY flag is set), as in both cases, 0 is returned, and, depending on the malformation, retlen may be set to 1. To disambiguate, upon a zero return, see if the first byte of s is 0 as well. If so, the input was a NUL; if not, the input had an error. Or you can use "utf8n_to_uvchr_error".

Note that this API requires disambiguation between successful decoding a NUL character, and an error return (unless the UTF8_CHECK_ONLY flag is set), as in both cases, 0 is returned. trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que esta API requiere la eliminación de ambigüedades entre la decodificación exitosa de un carácter NUL y un retorno de error (a menos que se establezca el indicador UTF8_CHECK_ONLY), ya que en ambos casos, se devuelve 0. Para eliminar la ambigüedad, con un retorno de cero, vea si el primer byte de s también es 0. Si es así, la entrada fue NUL ; si no, la entrada tuvo un error.

Note that this method considers a half-open TCP socket to be "in a connected state". Specifically, it does not distinguish between the ESTABLISHED and CLOSE-WAIT TCP states; it returns the peer address, rather than undef, in either case. Thus, in general, it cannot be used to reliably learn whether the peer has initiated a graceful shutdown because in most cases (see below) the local TCP state machine remains in CLOSE-WAIT until the local application calls "shutdown" in IO::Socket or close. Only at that point does this function return undef.

trans-unit.source: Note that you may have things stored in a lexicon besides just phrases for output: for example, if your program takes input from the keyboard, asking a "(Y/N)" question, you probably need to know what the equivalent of "Y[es]/N[o]" is in whatever language. You probably also need to know what the equivalents of the answers "y" and "n" are. You can store that information in the lexicon (say, under the keys "~answer_y" and "~answer_n", and the long forms as "~answer_yes" and "~answer_no", where "~" is just an ad-hoc character meant to indicate to programmers/translators that these are not phrases for output).

trans-unit.source: Note the undefs: where autogeneration results in the method for a standard operator which does not change either of its operands, such as - , being used to implement an operator which changes the operand ("mutators": here, -- and -= ), Perl passes undef as the third argument. This still evaluates as FALSE, consistent with the fact that the operands have not been swapped, but gives the subroutine a chance to alter its behaviour in these cases.
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta las undef s: donde la generación automática da como resultado el método para un operador estándar que no cambia ninguno de sus operandos, como - , que se usa para implementar un operador que cambia el operando ("mutadores": aquí, -- y -= ), Perl pasa undef como tercer argumento. Esto aún se evalúa como FALSO, de acuerdo con el hecho de que los operandos no se han intercambiado, pero le da a la subrutina la oportunidad de alterar su comportamiento en estos casos.

trans-unit.source: Note the tr// expression is surrounded by qq{}. The idea behind this is the same as the classic idiom that makes tr/// 'interpolate':

Note the undefs: where autogeneration results in the method for a standard operator which does not change either of its operands, such as -, being used to implement an operator which changes the operand ("mutators": here, -- and -=), Perl passes undef as the third argument. This still evaluates as FALSE, consistent with the fact that the operands have not been swapped, but gives the subroutine a chance to alter its behaviour in these cases.

trans-unit.source: Note the calls to PERL_SET_CONTEXT(). These are necessary to initialize the global state that tracks which interpreter is the "current" one on the particular process or thread that may be running it. It should always be used if you have more than one interpreter and are making perl API calls on both interpreters in an interleaved fashion.

trans-unit.source: Note the early capture of PL_savestack_ix to old_ss_ix, which is later passed as an arg to cx_pushblock. In the case of pp_entersub, this is because, although most values needing saving are stored in fields of the context struct, an extra value needs saving only when the debugger is running, and it doesn't make sense to bloat the struct for this rare case. So instead it is saved on the savestack. Since this value gets calculated and saved before the context is pushed, it is necessary to pass the old value of PL_savestack_ix to cx_pushblock, to ensure that the saved value gets freed during scope exit. For most users of cx_pushblock, where nothing needs pushing on the save stack, PL_savestack_ix is just passed directly as an arg to cx_pushblock.

Note the emphasis on bytes: even if the filehandle has been set to operate on characters (for example using the :encoding(UTF-8) I/O layer), the seek, tell, and sysseek family of functions use byte offsets, not character offsets, because seeking to a character offset would be very slow in a UTF-8 file.

Note the gaps marked by "*" before several of the byte entries above. These are caused by legal UTF-8 avoiding non-shortest encodings: it is technically possible to UTF-8-encode a single code point in different ways, but that is explicitly forbidden, and the shortest possible encoding should always be used (and that is what Perl does).
trans-unit.target: Fjese en los huecos marcados con "*" delante de varias de las entradas de bytes anteriores.stos se deben a que el UTF-8 legal evita las codificaciones no cortas:tcnicamente es posible codificar un nico punto de cdigo de diferentes maneras,pero eso est explcitamente prohibido,y siempre debe utilizarse la codificacin ms corta posible (y eso es lo que hace Perl).

trans-unit.source: Note to those still using Perl 5.18 or earlier: The use of $` , $& or $' will slow down all regex use within your program. Consult perlvar for @- to see equivalent expressions that won't cause slow down. See also Devel::SawAmpersand. Starting with Perl 5.10, you can also use the equivalent variables ${^PREMATCH} , ${^MATCH} and ${^POSTMATCH} , but for them to be defined, you have to specify the /p (preserve) modifier on your regular expression. In Perl 5.20, the use of $` , $& and $' makes no speed difference.
trans-unit.target: Nota para aquellos que todavía usan Perl 5.18 o anterior: El uso de $` , $& o $' ralentizará todo el uso de expresiones regulares en su programa. Consulte perlvar para @- para ver expresiones equivalentes que no causarán desaceleración. Consulte también Devel :: SawAmpersand . A partir de Perl 5.10, también puede usar las variables equivalentes ${^PREMATCH} , ${^MATCH} y ${^POSTMATCH} , pero para que se definan, debe especificar el modificador /p (preserve) en su expresión regular. En Perl 5.20, el uso de $` , $& y $' no hace ninguna diferencia de velocidad.

trans-unit.source: Note: Some sites have reported problems when using the file-access tests (-r , -w , and -x ) on files accessed via DEC's DFS. Specifically, since DFS does not currently provide access to the extended file header of files on remote volumes, attempts to examine the ACL fail, and the file tests will return false, with $! indicating that the file does not exist. You can use stat on these files, since that checks UIC-based protection only, and then manually check the appropriate bits, as defined by your C compiler's
trans-unit.target: Nota: Algunos sitios han informado problemas al usar las pruebas de acceso a archivos ( -r , -w y -x ) en archivos a los que se accede a través del DFS de DEC. Específicamente, dado que DFS no proporciona actualmente acceso al encabezado de archivo extendido de archivos en volúmenes remotos, los intentos de examinar la ACL fallan y las pruebas de archivo devolverán falso, con $! indicando que el archivo no existe. Puede usar stat en estos archivos, ya que solo verifica la protección basada en UIC, y luego verifica manualmente los bits apropiados, según lo definido por su compilador de C

Note: The policy of using locale rules for code points that can fit in a byte, and Unicode rules for those that can't is not uniformly applied. Pre-v5.12, it was somewhat haphazard; in v5.12 it was applied fairly consistently to regular expression matching except for bracketed character classes; in v5.14 it was extended to all regex matches; and in v5.16 to the casing operations such as \L and uc(). For collation, in all releases so far, the system's strxfrm() function is called, and whatever it does is what you get.
trans-unit.target: Nota: La política de usar reglas de configuración regional para puntos de código que pueden caber en un byte y reglas Unicode para aquellos que no pueden no se aplica de manera uniforme. Antes de la versión 5.12, era algo fortuito; en v5.12 se aplicó de manera bastante consistente a la coincidencia de expresiones regulares excepto para las clases de caracteres entre corchetes; en v5.14 se extendió a todas las coincidencias de expresiones regulares; y en v5.16 a las operaciones de mayúsculas y minúsculas como \L y uc() . Para la clasificación, en todas las versiones hasta ahora, se llama a la función strxfrm() del sistema , y lo que sea que haga es lo que se obtiene.

trans-unit.source: Note: The policy of using locale rules for code points that can fit in a byte, and Unicode rules for those that can't is not uniformly applied. Pre-v5.12, it was somewhat haphazard; in v5.12 it was applied fairly consistently to regular expression matching except for bracketed character classes; in v5.14 it was extended to all regex matches; and in v5.16 to the casing operations such as \L and uc(). For collation, in all releases so far, the system's strxfrm() function is called, and whatever it does is what you get. Starting in v5.26, various bugs are fixed with the way perl uses this function.
Note: This feature was introduced in version 5.57 of Exporter, released with perl 5.8.3.
trans-unit.target: Nota:Esta caracterstica fue introducida en la versin 5.57 de Exporter,lanzada con el perl 5.8.3.

trans-unit.source: Notice how both parameters to globmap are strings that are delimited by <>. This is done to make them look more like file globs - it is just syntactic sugar, but it can be handy when you want the strings to be visually distinctive. The enclosing <> are optional, so you don't have to use them - in fact the first thing globmap will do is remove these delimiters if they are present.
trans-unit.target: Observe cómo ambos parámetros del globmap son cadenas delimitadas por <>. Esto se hace para que se parezcan más a archivos globs; es solo azúcar sintáctico, pero puede ser útil cuando desea que las cadenas sean visualmente distintivas. Los <> adjuntos son opcionales, por lo que no tiene que usarlos; de hecho, lo primero que hará el mapa global es eliminar estos delimitadores si están presentes.

trans-unit.source: Notice how the second substitution stopped matching as soon as it encountered "y ". The *? quantifier effectively tells the regular expression engine to find a match as quickly as possible and pass control on to whatever is next in line, as you would if you were playing hot potato.
trans-unit.target: Observe cómo la segunda sustitución dejó de coincidir tan pronto como encontró "y". ¿El *? El cuantificador le dice al motor de expresiones regulares que encuentre una coincidencia lo más rápido posible y pase el control al siguiente en la fila, como lo haría si estuviera jugando a la papa caliente.

Notice that the final match matched q instead of p , which a match without the \G anchor would have done. Also note that the final match did not update pos. pos is only updated on a /g match. If the final match did indeed match p , it's a good bet that you're running a very old (pre-5.6.0) version of Perl.
trans-unit.target: Observe que la coincidencia final coincidió con q en lugar de p , lo que habría hecho una coincidencia sin el ancla \G También tenga en cuenta que el partido final no actualizó pos . pos solo se actualiza en la coincidencia a /g . Si la coincidencia final realmente coincidió con p , es una buena apuesta que esté ejecutando una versión muy antigua (anterior a 5.6.0) de Perl.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the final match matched q instead of p, which a match without the \G anchor would have done. Also note that the final match did not update pos. pos is only updated on a /g match. If the final match did indeed match p, it's a good bet that you're running an ancient (pre-5.6.0) version of Perl.

Notice that the outer bracket type has changed, and so our access syntax has also changed. That's because unlike C, in perl you can't freely interchange arrays and references thereto. $ref_to_AoA is a reference to an array, whereas @AoA is an array proper. Likewise, $AoA[2] is not an array, but an array ref. So how come you can write these:
trans-unit.target: Observe que el tipo de corchete exterior ha cambiado, por lo que nuestra sintaxis de acceso también ha cambiado. Eso es porque, a diferencia de C, en perl no se pueden intercambiar libremente matrices y referencias a ellas. $ ref_to_AoA es una referencia a una matriz, mientras que @AoA es una matriz propiamente dicha. Asimismo, $AoA[2] no es una matriz, sino una matriz ref. Entonces, ¿cómo es que puedes escribir esto?

trans-unit.source: Notice that the resulting directions might be somewhat surprising if you are looking at a flat worldmap: in such map projections the great circles quite often do not look like the shortest routes -- but for example the shortest possible routes from Europe or North America to Asia do often cross the polar regions. (The common Mercator projection does not show great circles as straight lines: straight lines in the Mercator projection are lines of constant bearing.)
trans-unit.target: Tenga en cuenta que las direcciones resultantes pueden ser algo sorprendentes si está mirando un mapamundi plano: en tales proyecciones de mapas, los grandes círculos a menudo no parecen las rutas más cortas, sino, por ejemplo, las rutas más cortas posibles desde Europa o América del Norte a Asia. a menudo cruzan las regiones polares. (La proyección de Mercator común no muestra los círculos máximos como líneas rectas: las líneas rectas en la proyección de Mercator son líneas de rumbo constante).

trans-unit.source: Notice the two lines commented with "XXXXX". If you check the first part of the typemap file (or section), you'll see that doubles are of type T_DOUBLE. In the INPUT part of the typemap, an argument that is T_DOUBLE is assigned to the variable arg by calling the routine SvNV on something, then casting it to double, then assigned to the variable arg. Similarly, in the OUTPUT section, once arg has its final value, it is passed to the sv_setnv function to be passed back to the calling subroutine. These two functions are explained in perlguts; we'll talk more later about what that "ST(0)" means in the section on the argument stack.
trans-unit.target: Observe las dos líneas comentadas con "XXXXX". Si marca la primera parte del archivo de mapa de tipos (o sección), verá que los dobles son de tipo T_DOUBLE. En la parte INPUT del typemap, un argumento que es T_DOUBLE se asigna a la variable arg llamando a la rutina SvNV en algo, luego convirtiéndolo en double y luego asignado a la variable arg. De manera similar, en la sección OUTPUT, una vez que arg tiene su valor final, se pasa a la función sv_setnv para volver a la subrutina de llamada. Estas dos funciones se explican en perlguts ; hablaremos más adelante sobre lo que significa "ST (0)" en la sección de la pila de argumentos.

trans-unit.source: Now all those different functions appear to exist independently. You can call red(), RED(), blue(), BLUE(), green(), etc. This technique saves on both compile time and memory use, and is less error-prone as well, since syntax checks happen at compile time. It's critical that any variables in the anonymous subroutine be lexicals in order to create a proper closure. That's the reasons for the my on the loop iteration variable.
trans-unit.target: Ahora todas esas funciones diferentes parecen existir de forma independiente. Puede llamar a red (), RED (), blue (), BLUE (), green (), etc. Esta técnica ahorra tiempo de compilación y uso de memoria, y también es menos propensa a errores, ya que las verificaciones de sintaxis ocurren en tiempo de compilación. Es fundamental que cualquier variable de la subrutina anónima sea léxica para crear un cierre adecuado. Esas son las razones de la variable de iteración my on the loop.

Now comes the clever bit. Lines in our ledger which are just income and not expenditure might end at column 46. Hence, we don't want to tell our unpack pattern that we need to find another 12 characters; we'll just say "if there's anything left, take it". As you might guess from regular expressions, that's what the * means: "use everything remaining".
trans-unit.target: Ahora viene la parte inteligente. Las líneas de nuestro libro mayor que son solo ingresos y no gastos pueden terminar en la columna 46. Por lo tanto, no queremos decirle a nuestro patrón de unpack que necesitamos encontrar otros 12 caracteres; simplemente diremos "si queda algo, tómalo". Como puede adivinar por las expresiones regulares, eso es lo que significa * : "usar todo lo que queda".

trans-unit.source: Now comes the clever bit. Lines in our ledger which are just income and not expenditure might end at column 46. Hence, we don't want to tell our unpack pattern that we need to find another 12 characters; we'll just say "if there's anything left, take it". As you might guess from regular expressions, that's what the * means: "use everything remaining".

trans-unit.source: Now suppose we have more than one interpreter instance running at the same time. This is feasible, but only if you used the Configure option -Dusemultiplicity or the options -Dusethreads -Duseithreads when building perl. By default, enabling one of these Configure options sets the per-interpreter global variable PL_perl_destruct_level to 1 , so that thorough cleaning is automatic and interpreter variables are initialized correctly. Even if you don't intend to run two or more interpreters at the same time, but to run them sequentially, like in the above example, it is recommended to build perl with the -Dusemultiplicity option otherwise some interpreter variables may not be initialized correctly between consecutive runs and your application may crash.
trans-unit.target: Ahora suponga que tenemos más de una instancia de intérprete ejecutándose al mismo tiempo. Esto es factible, pero solo si usó la opción Configurar -Dusemultiplicity o las opciones -Dusethreads -Duseithreads al compilar perl. De forma predeterminada, la activación de una de estas opciones de Configurar establece la variable global por intérprete PL_perl_destruct_level en 1 , de modo que la limpieza completa es automática y las variables del intérprete se inicializan correctamente. Incluso si no tiene la intención de ejecutar dos o más intérpretes al mismo tiempo, sino ejecutarlos secuencialmente, como en el ejemplo anterior, se recomienda compilar perl con la -Dusemultiplicity De lo contrario, es posible que algunas variables del intérprete no se inicialicen correctamente entre ejecuciones consecutivas y su aplicación se bloquee.

trans-unit.source: Now suppose we have more than one interpreter instance running at the same time. This is feasible, but only if you used the Configure option -Dusemultiplicity or the options -Dusethreads -Duseithreads when building perl. By default, enabling one of these Configure options sets the per-interpreter global variable PL_perl_destruct_level to 1, so that thorough cleaning is automatic and interpreter variables are initialized correctly. Even if you don't intend to run two or more interpreters at the same time, but to run them sequentially, like in the above example, it is recommended to build perl with the -Dusemultiplicity option otherwise some interpreter variables may not be initialized correctly between consecutive runs and your application may crash.

trans-unit.source: Now that I know how to subclass and replace TAP::Harness I can replace any other part of the harness. To do that I need to know which classes are responsible for which functionality. Here's a brief guided tour; the default class for each component is shown in parentheses. Normally any replacements I write will be subclasses of these default classes.

Now that UNTIE exists the class designer can decide which parts of the class functionality are really associated with untie and which with the object being destroyed. What makes sense for a given class depends on whether the inner references are being kept so that non-tie-related methods can be called on the object. But in most cases it probably makes sense to move the functionality that would have been in DESTROY to the UNTIE method.
trans-unit.target: Ahora que UNTIE existe, el diseñador de clases puede decidir qué partes de la funcionalidad de la clase están realmente asociadas con untie y cuáles con el objeto que se está destruyendo. Lo que tiene sentido para una clase determinada depende de si las referencias internas se mantienen de modo que se puedan invocar métodos no relacionados con vínculos en el objeto. Pero en la mayoría de los casos probablemente tenga sentido mover la funcionalidad que habría estado en DESTROY al método UNTIE.

trans-unit.source: Now that UNTIE exists the class designer can decide which parts of the class functionality are really associated with untie and which with the object being destroyed. What makes sense for a given class depends on whether the inner references are being kept so that non-tie-related methods can be called on the object. But in most cases it probably makes sense to move the functionality that would have been in DESTROY to the UNTIE method.

trans-unit.source: Now that the "native" mechanism is supported by Sys::Syslog and selected by default, the use of the setlogsock() function is discouraged because other mechanisms are less portable across operating systems. Authors of modules and programs that use this function, especially its cargo-cult form setlogsock("unix") , are advised to remove any occurrence of it unless they specifically want to use a given mechanism (like TCP or UDP to connect to a remote host).
trans-unit.target: Ahora que el mecanismo "nativo" es compatible con Sys::Syslog y está seleccionado de forma predeterminada, se desaconseja el uso de la función setlogsock() porque otros mecanismos son menos portátiles entre los sistemas operativos. Se recomienda a los autores de módulos y programas que utilizan esta función, especialmente su forma cargo-cult setlogsock("unix") , que eliminen cualquier aparición a menos que deseen específicamente utilizar un mecanismo determinado (como TCP o UDP para conectarse a un anfitrión).

trans-unit.source: Now that the "native" mechanism is supported by Sys::Syslog and selected by default, the use of the setlogsock() function is discouraged because other mechanisms are less portable across operating systems. Authors of modules and programs that use this function, especially its cargo-cult form setlogsock("unix"), are advised to remove any occurrence of it unless they specifically want to use a given mechanism (like TCP or UDP to connect to a remote host).

The answer lies behind the simple fact that an unpack with p promises a null-terminated string starting at the address taken from the buffer, and that implies a length for the data item to be returned:

Now that we have the *foo{THING} notation, typeglobs aren't used as much for filehandle manipulations, although they're still needed to pass brand new file and directory handles into or out of functions. That's because *HANDLE{IO} only works if HANDLE has already been used as a handle. In other words, *FH must be used to create new symbol table entries; *foo{THING} cannot. When in doubt, use *FH .
trans-unit.target: Ahora que tenemos la notación *foo{THING} THING } , los typeglobs no se usan tanto para manipulaciones de manejadores de archivos, aunque todavía son necesarios para pasar nuevos manejadores de archivos y directorios dentro o fuera de funciones. Eso es porque *HANDLE{IO} solo funciona si HANDLE ya se ha utilizado como identificador. En otras palabras, se debe usar *FH para crear nuevas entradas en la tabla de símbolos; *foo{THING} no puede. En caso de duda, utilice *FH .

trans-unit.source: Now that we have the *foo{THING} notation, typeglobs aren't used as much for filehandle manipulations, although they're still needed to pass brand new file and directory handles into or out of functions. That's because *HANDLE{IO} only works if HANDLE has already been used as a handle. In other words, *FH must be used to create new symbol table entries; *foo{THING} cannot. When in doubt, use *FH.

trans-unit.source: Now the parsing stage is complete, and the finished tree represents the operations that the Perl interpreter needs to perform to execute our program. Next, Perl does a dry run over the tree looking for optimisations: constant expressions such as 3 + 4 will be computed now, and the optimizer will also see if any multiple operations can be replaced with a single one. For instance, to fetch the variable $foo , instead of grabbing the glob *foo and looking at the scalar component, the optimizer fiddles the op tree to use a function which directly looks up the scalar in question. The main optimizer is peep in
trans-unit.target: Ahora la etapa de análisis está completa y el árbol terminado representa las operaciones que el intérprete de Perl necesita realizar para ejecutar nuestro programa. A continuación, Perl realiza un ensayo sobre el árbol en busca de optimizaciones: las expresiones constantes como 3 + 4 se calcularán ahora, y el optimizador también verá si se pueden reemplazar operaciones múltiples con una sola. Por ejemplo, para buscar la variable $foo , en lugar de tomar el glob *foo y mirar el componente escalar, el optimizador manipula el árbol de operaciones para usar una función que busca directamente el escalar en cuestión. El optimizador principal es peep in

trans-unit.source: Now we have a special case. The EXACT regop has a regnext of 0. This is because if it matches it should try to match itself again. The PLUS regop handles the actual failure of the EXACT regop and acts appropriately (going to regnode 6 if the EXACT matched at least once, or failing if it didn't).
trans-unit.target: Ahora tenemos un caso especial. El regop EXACT O tiene un regnext de 0. Esto se debe a que si coincide, debería intentar hacerlo de nuevo. El regop PLUS maneja la falla real del regop EXACT O y actúa apropiadamente (yendo a regnode 6 si el EXACT coincidió al menos una vez, o fallando si no lo hizo).
